content.body:
What Iâ€™m wondering is if I can get away with claiming that call-this does not overlap with the pipe operator, since trying to use `.call` with the pipe operator solves the word order aloneâ€¦but it doesnâ€™t make the clunkiness betterâ€”it makes it worse.
```js
fn.call(rec, arg) // Unnatural word order
rec |> fn.call(@, arg) // Natural word order but worsened readability
rec :> f(arg)
```

content.body:
Richard Gibson gave me this idea at the Research Call today.

Since we must have both pipe operator and call-this, itâ€™s going to be important to convey the idea that pipe operator does not solve `.call`â€™s clunkiness problem, and that another operator is necessary. (SlideÂ 6 in the call-this presentation talks about this too.)

content.body: I think there _is_ overlap in the sense that a pipe operator allows for expression an invocation in SVO order like `receiver |> method.call(@Ì‚%Ì‚, ...args)`, but I also like the idea of strikethrough on the pipe examples under call-this to indicate that they don't really address the clunkiness motivation for it. So basically, a combination of the two diagramsâ€”graphical layout of the first, textual formatting of the second.

content.body: but also, in the wake of today's meeting and to further separate call-this from pipelines, I think it would make sense to update both the diagram and the slides to replace the `:>` example punctuator for call-this with something more suggestive of tight binding, e.g. `~>` (I understand it could change, but this seems like a "best foot forward" approach)
